Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Bo Zhang of the University of Washington is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry to introduce and utilize a fluorescence-based analytical method to increase the sensitivity of electrochemical detection. A key concept of this method is to use a fluorogenic reaction to report the kinetics of a conventional electrochemical reaction of interest, e.g., oxidation of dopamine. As such, this method could significantly improve sensitivity in electrochemical detection and enable new capability. This project will focus on developing a more comprehensive understanding of coupled reactions on bipolar microelectrodes and optimizing fluorescence-enabled electrochemical detection to achieve single-molecule sensitivity.

This new analytical strategy could have significant impact on many important fields, such as neurochemistry, environmental analysis, and electrocatalysis. This work will provide excellent training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of electrochemistry, sensing, and fluorescence microscopy. Graduate and undergraduate students, including female students and minority students, will be recruited into this research program. They will be actively involved in numerous training opportunities such as using state-of-the-art analytical instruments, designing new electrochemical experiments and analyzing results, presenting at group meetings and attending national conferences, and publishing in leading journals in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award has enabled the PI Zhang and his group to develop a new concept in electroanalytical chemistry which enables the use of fluorescence to report electrochemical current signal on very large electrochemical arrays. This new method, fluorescence-enabled electrochemical microscopy or FEEM, utilizes a bipolar electrode to couple two separate redox reactions on one electrode. One reaction is the reaction of interest, such as oxidation of dopamine released from a neuronal cell and the other one is a fluorogenic redox reaction, which converts a non-fluorescent molecule to a highly fluorescent product. This allows one to use fluorescence microscopy to amplify and directly visualize electrochemical signal. This NSF award has allowed us to train five graduate students, three of which has graduated with a Ph.D. degree. This award has resulted in more than six publications in leading journals in the analytical chemistry field. The PI and his graduate students have been supported to present nearly 20 presentations and seminars at universities and national and international meetings.

Intellectual Merit

Imaging diffusion at an Ultramicroelectrode (UME).  We have recently reported (Anal. Chem., 2014, 86, 12299-12307) the use of FEEM to directly image transient radial diffusion profile on an UME. FEEM is demonstrated as a new technique to image transient concentration profiles of redox species generated on an UME using an array of thousands of parallel bipolar microelectrodes. This technique provides a way to image an entire 2-D lateral cross section of a dynamic diffusion layer in a single experiment. By taking several of these lateral cross sections at different axial positions in the diffusion layer, a 3-D image of the diffusion layer can be built.

Toward single molecule sensitivity. We have made considerable progress on the use of FEEM to study single molecule electrochemistry. The goal of this research is to achieve ultimate sensitivity in electrochemical detection by converting a faradic signal to a fluorescence signal. The use of resazurin to study oxidation of single ferrocene molecule will soon be reported.

Broader Impacts

This project develops a unique electroanalytical tool for neuronal imaging, biomedical sensing, and low-level environmental analysis. This NSF grant has supported the PI and numerous graduate students to Pittcon, IUPAC conference in Korea, and many other meetings. The PI has delivered 15 invited departmental seminars. Three Ph.D. students have graduated: Jonathan Cox, Joshua Guerrette, and Marissa Wood. Students have been awarded numerous awards including two ACS graduate fellowships, one SEAC student travel award, and one award to attend Lindau Nobel laureate meeting. Three undergraduate students have been supported to work on this project. Moreover, the PI is on the Features Board of Anal. Chem., a member of Board of Directors for SEAC, and a discussion leader of 2014 GRC on Electrochemistry. 


Last Modified: 08/17/2015
Modified by: Bo Zhang
